TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit StatisticFormula extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Calculates statistical formulas.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Formulas can be loosely grouped into the following categories: distributions, including inverse distributions; tests; and basic statistical formulas. Each group has common characteristics with respect to their input and return values.

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.AnovaResult Anova (double probability, string inputSeriesNames);
.method public hidebysig instance class System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.AnovaResult Anova(float64 probability, string inputSeriesNames) cil managed
Public Function Anova (probability As Double, inputSeriesNames As String) As AnovaResult
public: System::Web::UI::DataVisualization::Charting::AnovaResult ^ Anova(double probability, System::String ^ inputSeriesNames);
member this.Anova : double * string -> System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.AnovaResult

Docs.param: Alpha value. The acceptable input range is between 0 and 1.
Names of two or more input series. Each series must exist in the series collection at the time of the method call, and have the same number of data points.
Docs.summary: The Anova formula determines the existence or absence of a statistically significant difference between the mean values of two or more groups of data.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As AnovaResult = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Anova(.05, "Series1,Series2,Series3") ```
```csharp AnovaResult result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Anova(.05, "Series1,Series2,Series3"); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public double BetaFunction (double m, double n);
.method public hidebysig instance float64 BetaFunction(float64 m, float64 n) cil managed
Public Function BetaFunction (m As Double, n As Double) As Double
public: double BetaFunction(double m, double n);
member this.BetaFunction : double * double -> double

Docs.param: First value for the beta function.
Second value for the beta function.
Docs.summary: The beta function calculates the beta function value.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As Double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.BetaFunction(2.3, 6.2) ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.BetaFunction(2.3, 6.2); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public double Correlation (string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName);
.method public hidebysig instance float64 Correlation(string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName) cil managed
Public Function Correlation (firstInputSeriesName As String, secondInputSeriesName As String) As Double
public: double Correlation(System::String ^ firstInputSeriesName, System::String ^ secondInputSeriesName);
member this.Correlation : string * string -> double

Docs.param: Name of the object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the object that stores the second group's data.
Docs.summary: The correlation formula shows the strength of the relationship that exists between two random variables.
Docs.returns: Correlation value between the two groups of data.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The method throws an exception if the input series do not have the same number of data points.
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As Double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Correlation("Series1", "Series2") ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Correlation("Series1", "Series2"); ```

Public Function Covariance (firstInputSeriesName As String, secondInputSeriesName As String) As Double
public: double Covariance(System::String ^ firstInputSeriesName, System::String ^ secondInputSeriesName);
member this.Covariance : string * string -> double

Docs.param: Name of the object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the object that stores the second group's data.
Docs.summary: The covariance formula measures the degree of dependence that may exist between two random variables.
Docs.returns: Covariance value between the two groups of data.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The method throws an exception if the input series do not have the same number of data points.
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Covariance("Series1", "Series2") ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Covariance("Series1", "Series2"); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public double FDistribution (double value, int firstDegreeOfFreedom, int secondDegreeOfFreedom);
.method public hidebysig instance float64 FDistribution(float64 value, int32 firstDegreeOfFreedom, int32 secondDegreeOfFreedom) cil managed
Public Function FDistribution (value As Double, firstDegreeOfFreedom As Integer, secondDegreeOfFreedom As Integer) As Double
public: double FDistribution(double value, int firstDegreeOfFreedom, int secondDegreeOfFreedom);
member this.FDistribution : double * int * int -> double

Docs.param: The F value for which you want the distribution.
First degree of freedom.
Second degree of freedom.
Docs.summary: The F distribution formula calculates the probability for the F-distribution.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.FDistribution(6.31, 15, 7) ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.FDistribution(6.31, 15, 7); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.FTestResult FTest (double probability, string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName);
.method public hidebysig instance class System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.FTestResult FTest(float64 probability, string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName) cil managed
Public Function FTest (probability As Double, firstInputSeriesName As String, secondInputSeriesName As String) As FTestResult
public: System::Web::UI::DataVisualization::Charting::FTestResult ^ FTest(double probability, System::String ^ firstInputSeriesName, System::String ^ secondInputSeriesName);
member this.FTest : double * string * string -> System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.FTestResult

Docs.param: The alpha value. The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Name of the object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the object that stores the second group's data.
Docs.summary: The F-test formula performs a two-sample F-test using F distribution, and is used to see if the samples have different variances.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The method throws an exception if the input series do not have the same number of data points.
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As FTestResult = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.FTest(0.05, "Series1", "Series2") ```
```csharp FTestResult result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.FTest(0.05, "Series1", "Series2"); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public double InverseFDistribution (double probability, int firstDegreeOfFreedom, int secondDegreeOfFreedom);
.method public hidebysig instance float64 InverseFDistribution(float64 probability, int32 firstDegreeOfFreedom, int32 secondDegreeOfFreedom) cil managed
Public Function InverseFDistribution (probability As Double, firstDegreeOfFreedom As Integer, secondDegreeOfFreedom As Integer) As Double
public: double InverseFDistribution(double probability, int firstDegreeOfFreedom, int secondDegreeOfFreedom);
member this.InverseFDistribution : double * int * int -> double

Docs.param: Probability for the F distribution. The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
First degree of freedom.
Second degree of freedom.
Docs.summary: The inverse F distribution formula calculates the inverse of the F cumulative distribution.
Docs.returns: F value for the F distribution.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As Double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.InverseFDistribution(.05, 15, 30) ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.InverseFDistribution(.05, 15, 30); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public double InverseNormalDistribution (double probability);
.method public hidebysig instance float64 InverseNormalDistribution(float64 probability) cil managed
Public Function InverseNormalDistribution (probability As Double) As Double
public: double InverseNormalDistribution(double probability);
member this.InverseNormalDistribution : double -> double

Docs.param: Alpha value. The acceptable input range is between 0 and 1.
Docs.summary: The inverse normal distribution formula calculates the inverse of the standard normal cumulative distribution. The distribution has a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of one.
Docs.returns: Inverse of the normal distribution function.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.InverseNormalDistribution(.05) ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.InverseNormalDistribution(.05); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public double InverseTDistribution (double probability, int degreeOfFreedom);
.method public hidebysig instance float64 InverseTDistribution(float64 probability, int32 degreeOfFreedom) cil managed
Public Function InverseTDistribution (probability As Double, degreeOfFreedom As Integer) As Double
public: double InverseTDistribution(double probability, int degreeOfFreedom);
member this.InverseTDistribution : double * int -> double

Docs.param: Probability for the F distribution. The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Degree of freedom.
Docs.summary: The inverse *t*-distribution formula calculates the *t*-value of the Student's *t*-distribution as a function of probability and degrees of freedom.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.InverseTDistribution(.05, 15) ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.InverseTDistribution(.05, 15); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public double Mean (string inputSeriesName);
.method public hidebysig instance float64 Mean(string inputSeriesName) cil managed
Public Function Mean (inputSeriesName As String) As Double
public: double Mean(System::String ^ inputSeriesName);
member this.Mean : string -> double

Docs.param: Name of the object that stores the data for which the mean value is required.
Docs.summary: The mean formula calculates the average, or mean, of data stored in a data series.
Docs.returns: Mean value of all the data points in the given series.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If named input series does not exist in the <xref:System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.SeriesCollection> at the time of the method call, an exception is thrown.
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As Double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Mean("Series1") ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Mean("Series1"); ```

Public Function Median (inputSeriesName As String) As Double
public: double Median(System::String ^ inputSeriesName);
member this.Median : string -> double

Docs.param: Name of the object that stores the data for which the median value is required.
Docs.summary: The median formula calculates the median of the data stored in a data series.
Docs.returns: Median of all the data points in the given series.

remarks.format:
## Remarks If the named input series does not exist in the <xref:System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.SeriesCollection> at the time of the method call, an exception is thrown.
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As Double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Median("Series1") ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Median("Series1"); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public double NormalDistribution (double zValue);
.method public hidebysig instance float64 NormalDistribution(float64 zValue) cil managed
Public Function NormalDistribution (zValue As Double) As Double
public: double NormalDistribution(double zValue);
member this.NormalDistribution : double -> double

Docs.param: Value for which the normal distribution is required.
Docs.summary: The normal distribution formula calculates the value of the standard normal cumulative distribution. The distribution has a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.
Docs.returns: Value of the standard normal cumulative distribution.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As Double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.NormalDistribution(1.96) ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.NormalDistribution(1.96); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public double TDistribution (double value, int degreeOfFreedom, bool oneTail);
.method public hidebysig instance float64 TDistribution(float64 value, int32 degreeOfFreedom, bool oneTail) cil managed
Public Function TDistribution (value As Double, degreeOfFreedom As Integer, oneTail As Boolean) As Double
public: double TDistribution(double value, int degreeOfFreedom, bool oneTail);
member this.TDistribution : double * int * bool -> double

Docs.param: t-value for which you want the distribution.
Degree of freedom
If set to , one-tailed distribution is used. Otherwise, two-tailed distribution is used.
Docs.summary: The *t*-distribution formula calculates the probability for the Student's *t*-distribution.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As Double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.TDistribution(1.96, 30, true) ```
```csharp double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.TDistribution(1.96, 30, true); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult TTestEqualVariances (double hypothesizedMeanDifference, double probability, string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName);

.method public hidebysig instance class System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult TTestEqualVariances(float64 hypothesizedMeanDifference, float64 probability, string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName) cil managed
Public Function TTestEqualVariances (hypothesizedMeanDifference As Double, probability As Double, firstInputSeriesName As String, secondInputSeriesName As String) As TTestResult

public: System::Web::UI::DataVisualization::Charting::TTestResult ^ TTestEqualVariances(double hypothesizedMeanDifference, double probability, System::String ^ firstInputSeriesName, System::String ^ secondInputSeriesName);
member this.TTestEqualVariances : double * double * string * string -> System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult

Docs.param: Hypothesized difference between the means of the data groups.
Alpha value. The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Name of the object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the object that stores the second group's data.
Docs.summary: The *t*-test with equal variances formula performs a *t*-test using Student's *t*-distribution with equal variances.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As TTestResult = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.TTestPaired(0.2, 0.05, "Series1", "Series2") ```
```csharp TTestResult result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.TTestPaired(0.2, 0.05, "Series1", "Series2"); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult TTestPaired (double hypothesizedMeanDifference, double probability, string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName);

.method public hidebysig instance class System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult TTestPaired(float64 hypothesizedMeanDifference, float64 probability, string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName) cil managed
Public Function TTestPaired (hypothesizedMeanDifference As Double, probability As Double, firstInputSeriesName As String, secondInputSeriesName As String) As TTestResult

public: System::Web::UI::DataVisualization::Charting::TTestResult ^ TTestPaired(double hypothesizedMeanDifference, double probability, System::String ^ firstInputSeriesName, System::String ^ secondInputSeriesName);
member this.TTestPaired : double * double * string * string -> System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult

Docs.param: Hypothesized difference between the means of the data groups.
Alpha value. The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Name of the object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the object that stores the second group's data.
Docs.summary: The *t*-test paired formula performs a *t*-test using Student's *t*-distribution with paired samples. This is useful when there is an observed natural pairing in samples (for example, when a sample group is tested twice).

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As TTestResult = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.TTestPaired(0.2, 0.05, "Series1", "Series2") ```
```csharp TTestResult result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.TTestPaired(0.2, 0.05, "Series1", "Series2"); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult TTestUnequalVariances (double hypothesizedMeanDifference, double probability, string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName);

Public Function TTestUnequalVariances (hypothesizedMeanDifference As Double, probability As Double, firstInputSeriesName As String, secondInputSeriesName As String) As TTestResult

public: System::Web::UI::DataVisualization::Charting::TTestResult ^ TTestUnequalVariances(double hypothesizedMeanDifference, double probability, System::String ^ firstInputSeriesName, System::String ^ secondInputSeriesName);
member this.TTestUnequalVariances : double * double * string * string -> System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.TTestResult

Docs.param: Hypothesized difference between the means of the data groups.
Alpha value. The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Name of the object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the object that stores the second group's data.
Docs.summary: The *t*-test with unequal variances formula performs a *t*-test using Student's *t*-distribution with unequal variances.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As TTestResult = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.TTestUnEqualVariances(0.2, 0.05, "Series1", "Series2") ```
```csharp TTestResult result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.TTestUnEqualVariances(0.2, 0.05, "Series1", "Series2"); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public double Variance (string inputSeriesName, bool sampleVariance);
.method public hidebysig instance float64 Variance(string inputSeriesName, bool sampleVariance) cil managed
Public Function Variance (inputSeriesName As String, sampleVariance As Boolean) As Double
public: double Variance(System::String ^ inputSeriesName, bool sampleVariance);
member this.Variance : string * bool -> double

Docs.param: Name of the object that stores the data for which the mean value is required.
Specify if the data is a sample of a population; and if the data is the entire population.
Docs.summary: The variance formula calculates the variance within a group of data.
Docs.returns: Variance within the group of data.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As Double = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Variance("Series1", false) ```
```csharp TTestResult result = double result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.Variance("Series1", false); ```

MemberSignature.Value: public System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.ZTestResult ZTest (double hypothesizedMeanDifference, double varianceFirstGroup, double varianceSecondGroup, double probability, string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName);

.method public hidebysig instance class System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.ZTestResult ZTest(float64 hypothesizedMeanDifference, float64 varianceFirstGroup, float64 varianceSecondGroup, float64 probability, string firstInputSeriesName, string secondInputSeriesName) cil managed

Public Function ZTest (hypothesizedMeanDifference As Double, varianceFirstGroup As Double, varianceSecondGroup As Double, probability As Double, firstInputSeriesName As String, secondInputSeriesName As String) As ZTestResult

public: System::Web::UI::DataVisualization::Charting::ZTestResult ^ ZTest(double hypothesizedMeanDifference, double varianceFirstGroup, double varianceSecondGroup, double probability, System::String ^ firstInputSeriesName, System::String ^ secondInputSeriesName);
member this.ZTest : double * double * double * double * string * string -> System.Web.UI.DataVisualization.Charting.ZTestResult
MemberSignature.Usage: statisticFormula.ZTest (hypothesizedMeanDifference, varianceFirstGroup, varianceSecondGroup, probability, firstInputSeriesName, secondInputSeriesName)

Docs.param: Hypothesized difference between the means of the data groups.
Variance within the first group of data.
Variance within the second group of data.
Alpha value. The acceptable range is between 0 and 1.
Name of the object that stores the first group's data.
Name of the object that stores the second group's data.
Docs.summary: The Z-test formula performs a Z-test using normal distribution.

remarks.format:
## Examples The following code demonstrates how to use this formula.
```vb Dim result As ZTestResult = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.ZTest(0.2, 2.5, 4.5, 0.05, "Series1", "Series2") ```
```csharp ZTestResult result = Chart1.DataManipulator.Statistics.ZTest(0.2, 2.5, 4.5, 0.05, "Series1", "Series2"); ```
